question: In alpha particle scattering experiment, if v is the initial velocity of the particle, then the distance of closest approach is d. If the velocity is doubled, then the distance of closest approach becomes
explanation: Distance of closest approach <katex>$d$</katex> is obtained by equating initial KE to potential energy at closest approach: <katex>$\frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{kQq}{d}$</katex>.
If <katex>$v$</katex> is doubled (<katex>$2v$</katex>), <katex>$d$</katex> becomes <katex>$\frac{1}{(2)^2} = \frac{1}{4}$</katex> of the original value.
